articles.title: Ephemeris
articles.summary: This article, titled "Ephemeris," provides a detailed calendar of events for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) for September and October. It lists various activities including indoor and outdoor star parties, board meetings, and general meetings featuring guest speakers like Dr. Sy Stein from NASA Ames discussing space medicine research. The document also includes membership information and contact details for the SJAA.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The article reports on the August SJAA board meeting, detailing the new Treasurer, Bob Fingerhut, and the creation of an Observatory Building Fund. It announces a joint star party with the Central Coast Astronomical Society at Chews Ridge and emphasizes the urgent need for volunteers to assist with Bulletin production and article submissions. Additionally, it includes a get-well wish for Mrs. Gregory and promotes an astronomy writing contest.

articles.title: General Meeting
articles.summary: Dr. Sandra Faber of Lick Observatory spoke at the August SJAA General Meeting, detailing Lick's successful efforts to persuade the San Jose City Council to install low-pressure sodium (LPS) streetlights to combat light pollution. She explained the technical advantages of LPS lights for astronomical research over high-pressure sodium (HPS) lights due to their easily removable emission lines. Faber also discussed potential differences in streetlight preferences between amateur and professional astronomers, though the SJAA audience largely supported LPS.

articles.title: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: This 'Letters to the Editor' section features Penny Pinschmidt's offer of a club 12-1/2" telescope, which currently lacks interested takers, and an editor's inquiry about another member's 6" telescope. It also includes a reminder of the club's two-month telescope loan policy for members. Additionally, Andy Fraknoi from the A.S.P. issues a correction for the Astronomical Society of the Pacific's mailing address.

articles.title: Ads
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is offering custom 1x3 inch black-and-gold nameplates with their logo for $3, available for order through Jack Selders at club meetings or by mail. The article also features humorous quotes from board members Jim Van Nuland and Jay Freeman regarding food preferences during discussions about an AANC Xmas Conference.

articles.title: The Celestial Tourist Speaks
articles.summary: The article by Jay Reynolds Freeman offers practical advice for amateur astronomers introducing beginners to telescope observing, emphasizing common pitfalls that can deter newcomers. It recommends explaining telescope operation first, starting with familiar and bright celestial objects, ensuring physical comfort, and structuring an observing session as a 'tour of the universe' to foster engagement and lasting interest in astronomy.

articles.title: IMPRESSIONS OF JULY'S LUNAR ECLIPSE
articles.summary: The author recounts his experience observing a lunar eclipse from Henry Coe Park, a dark-sky site, accompanied by fellow observers. Despite some challenges like a diffuse shadow edge and residual moonlight affecting occultation timings, the dark sky allowed for excellent views of planets, deep-sky objects like the Trifid Nebula and M22, and the Milky Way. The move to the dark site significantly enhanced the aesthetic appreciation of the eclipse and the surrounding night sky.

articles.title: Eleventh Annual Tehachapi Mountain Telescope Makers Star Party
articles.summary: The Eleventh Annual Tehachapi Mountain Telescope Makers Star Party is scheduled for Saturday, September 18, 1982, at Antelope Canyon Ranch in the Tehachapi Mountains at 7500 feet elevation. Sponsored by several astronomical societies, its purpose is to foster the art and science of telescope making through idea exchange and observation under ideal conditions. The event details include registration fees, camping options, traffic schedules for the one-lane access road, and a new moon coinciding with the event.

articles.title: Comet Comments
articles.summary: This article, titled "Comet Comments" by Don Machholz, provides updates on several comets in the 1982 sky, including the recent discovery of Comet Austin (1982g) and its discoverer, Rodney Austin, along with observations for Periodic Comets Peters-Hartley (1982h), D'Arrest (1982e), and Churyumov-Gerasimenko (1982f). It also features a retrospective on the highly publicized but publicly disappointing Comet Kohoutek (1973 XII), drawing parallels to temper expectations for the upcoming Halley's Comet in 1986. The article includes orbital details, magnitudes, and visibility notes for these celestial objects.

articles.title: Space Program Update
articles.summary: The 'Space Program Update' details recent advancements and future plans across various space agencies, covering topics from Earth observation to deep space missions. Key highlights include the space shuttle's imaging radar revealing subsurface features in the Sahara, congressional funding for NASA's Centaur upper stage and Galileo mission, and the successful deorbit of the Soviet Salyut-6 while Salyut-7 received new cosmonauts. The article also discusses potential Mars and Venus mapping missions, plans for additional Space Shuttle orbiters, and the future development of a manned space station.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: Gerry Rattley provides an update on his ongoing Herschel object observing project, detailing plans to observe more objects, prepare deep-sky observing articles for a bulletin series, and eventually publish a comprehensive Herschel Catalogue. The article also includes corrections to previous Herschel object discussions and a detailed update on the Coma Galaxy Cluster, highlighting discrepancies in galaxy identifications (IC4021/4026, NGC4886/4882, NGC4872/4874) when compared to the Webb Society Handbook and RNGC.

articles.title: HOW TO GET THERE
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions from downtown Tehachapi to Antelope Canyon Ranch, guiding attendees to a Star Party registration and an observing site. It specifies street names, turn directions, and distances, passing through Tehachapi Mountain County Park. A basic map illustrates the route and key landmarks along the way.

articles.title: NEWS MATERIAL
articles.summary: This document is a fragment of the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) Bulletin, providing the organization's address. It also features a map indicating various SJAA meeting and star party locations, with a date reference of April 29, 1984.
